The ANOVA results showed that there was a significant difference between the mean of the components obtained for each of the essential oils of S. hydrangea flowers and leaves (P ≤ 0.05). The most abundant components in the essential oil from leaves were (+)-spathulenol (16.07%), 1,8-cineole (13.96%), trans-caryophyllene (9.58%), β-pinene (8.91%), β-eudesmol (5.33%), camphor (4.06%) and α-pinene (3.61%) (Table 1 and Fig. 1), in accordance with the findings of Ghannadi et al.
32 . However, (+)-spathulenol, β-eudesmol, trans-caryophyllene and camphor were detected for the first time in this study. Again, habitat and climate changes may affect the composition of the extractive products, as growth and growth stages, farming and genetic characteristics may vary significantly
40 .
